column17:
The introduction to classes would have helped me more if it was presented last week already.

I have a hard time with Jessies talks. I sometimes wished that he would focus more on certain parts and use the extra time to slow down a little bit. Might be just me though.

First off, I want to say that I was very impressed with the speaker this past Thursday. He was awesome. After last week's dud speaker, I was a little apprehensive about this week's speaker and had very high expectations. Dave delivered and I appreciated his honest and helpful responses.

I think the group greatly benefitted from all the extra help from the Chicago instructors. I know it's not sustainable, but having a large teacher to student ratio was great, and I could see that each group was getting the attention they needed.

I had an extremely productive Thursday, coding wise. I think that I actually learn more and retain the concepts better when I solo code myself. I'm forced to really figure the problems out on my own and get to type every single line of code myself. After, once I completed my tasks, I felt more motivated to get up and help other people. I hope that we have more solo-coding time. In an idea situation, for very problem we would have a short amount of time to tackle the problem ourself, and then have an option to pair or go help other people.

As a beginner, it is tough for me to get much info out of a lecture that isn't laser focused.  When the person lecturing goes on a number of tangents, I lose my focus as a learner and fail to keep the "big picture" or the "point" of the lecture in mind.  I would appreciate the lectures being laser focused and then the students/teachers asking questions that might lead to tangents doing so at the end.

Also, I enjoy thinking about what I'm learning at a bunch of random points during my day (eg while I'm in the shower).  Last week, I found it incredibly easy to go over things I learned and practice writing code in my mind.  This week, I found it more difficult.  I have two guesses as to why.  The first is that I occasionally struggled to see how some of the challenges related to the OO theme for the week.  For example, for a challenge like 'reading CSV', why was the shell code written as classes and how would it look if the program was procedural?  This left me wondering, why is this difference significant?  Because of this, I think my mind was focusing on structuring the world around me instead of concentrating on what I'm learning.  My second guess is that the focus of this week was slightly more broad than last week.  So whereas I might have played around with the 'map' method in my mind last week, I instead try to build a class while I'm taking a shower (proves to me much more difficult).  

Thanks for another great week and I look forward to learning more with you all.

Because I'm feeling this way, I was hoping that we could maybe set up some kind of a one-on-one checkin for me (and any other person that would like it) to let a staff member know exactly where I am on the challenges and get some feedback on prioritization. One of my struggles is knowing what part of the material is the most important. Also, I was wondering if there will be any specific one-on-one instruction from a teacher for those of us that are behind. Brick sat with me for a while during solo time this Thursday, and it was really helpful because he slowed the pace down and walked through some things I was struggling with.

I felt this week did a great job of tying concepts together and I am a big fan of OOP. I realize we need some groundwork before OOP starts to entirely make sense as a concept, but I think it would have been good to talk about it from Day 1, or to have been assigned an OOP book or something as part of our prep work. At this point I'm aware of exactly how basic our prep work was, and I believe it would have made a huge difference in how confident I currently feel to have been assigned like 3 times as much with twice as long to work on it, including materials covering OOP and some of the more overarching concepts. I wanted to start preparing 4 months in advance, but had little idea of where to direct my learning, and feel like without any guidance I chose poorly. Prep felt like a bit of a rush job, on both the DBC end and my end.

Huge fan of going over in a group a few of the prior challenges, either as code review or someone doing the problem from scratch, gives good insight into other approaches and/or best practices. 

Loved having the Chicago group here, it was awesome to have even more people helping out and they were very solid teachers. Dave's talk was insightful as someone who's essentially been in our shoes. A night where my pair's mentor (who is a developer) was in and helped us work through the hospital problem was very very useful, both on logic and just having someone to ask questions in the evening. For future reference if there is any way to get a collection of mentors for the cohort who could come in one evening every 3 weeks or something, that would be very helpful. Having even one person around in the evenings who completely knows what they're doing could make a huge difference.

To me, it's learning as much as I can, but I gather from students it's learn as much as you can by get things done.  When it's the ladder, it creates poor pairing experiences because when I act entitled to my learning experience pairs like Eno and Ryan  M want to separate so they can charge ahead.

I really appreciated that we were able to talk and she set a lot of my fears and anxiety to rest. I can't say enough about how great all the instructors have been and I'm always so thankful for their kind and generous support.

column17: Alright, this will be long but I feel like I have to get it out…   I really like the idea oft he pink post-it notes and think this should be the only way to ask for help (currently you can still “cut the line” by getting up an speaking to the teacher directly which kind of defends the purpose not wasting time on looking out for a teacher).   I really didn’t like the joke we played on Sherrif. Makes me still feel bad when I think about it.  I also don't like that you told us that his talk will be later that day at 5pm but than just canceled it without telling anyone. If you want to change the schedule twice a day that is one thing but at least tell everyone.     An unrelated suggestion would be to have an email or something where we can send random suggestions on how to improve DevBootcamp. I’m sure there would be a gem in it once in a while.   2 ideas from me: 1.     Make sure the panic button at the front door is labeled as that more prominent. 2.     Consider changing your “Now start the prep work” email with regard to the time required. One might plan accordingly and thus underestimate the real time needed which in my case would have been > 100 hours (my fault to interpret the email the way I wanted but why not be on the safe side and make sure it can not be misunderstood).   What I really don’t like is that you did not mention the whole “we might kick you out after 3 or 6 weeks” thing before DevBootcamp started. You seem to take pride in not grading but what else is this test? If you fail (= get an f) you will be kicked out? For some people who didn’t know about that beforehand and who might not be able to extend their time (due to visa issues or other arrangements), having to repeat three weeks and being kicked is basically the same thing.  What now follows might be only due to me not getting enough sleep the last couple of days but thinking of the iceberg you’ll get it all and raw anyway.  I really don’t like the whole testing stuff (see above). Indepent from if I’ll make it or not or if I can extend my stay or not it just makes me feel very bad and is a HUGE distraction (for me). It’s hard to estimate but I currently guess that I lost close to a whole day of productivity just by thinking of the test, again and again and therefore could not sleep and therefore being tired… On top of that comes what it does to my mood. I disliked the test idea as soon as I heard about it (which I think was far to late -> see above) but it really kicked in this week. What adds to my not liking the test stuff is that I don’t get the point off it. I don’t want to learn how to learn with such kind of pressure. Maybe it will help some other people on how to approach interviews and stuff but it just doesn’t work for me. I would have liked to practice interviews without them being combined with this whole ‘we might kick you out afterwards’ thing since I approach real job interviews very different than I approached this test today. There are potentially thousands of companies I can apply to so if one rejects me it’s not that big off a deal. On the other hand I will not be able to join such a program again for the foreseeable future (due to time, money and visa issues) so it feels like much more is at stake than it would be in an job interview. Bla, bla, bla, I think you get my point.  I do see that you have to look out for the people who fall behind and that it might not be a good idea for some to continue but why not use all of the information you have about us, all the feedback we got from our pairs… and once you get the feeling that someone might not fit in / falls to far begin speak to him/her, speak to him/her again, maybe get an outsider to speak to him her and than suggest to repeat some of the program? Why does it all have to be on one day where a lot of people just feel like shit, couldn’t sleep (and had to get up even earlier), get freaked out by stage fright… You have more experience than I but I just don’t see how this is supposed to add to an optimal learning environment.  Again this might be about some skill some people are interested in but I’m not. I can’t remember when the last time was I needed it (even when changing jobs) and since I really don’t like practicing it under realistic conditions I really wished that this would not be part of Devbootcamp.  Alright, that’s it. I’m sure I don’t need to tell you that this is just an unfiltered rand of some sleep-deprived dude who is just disappointed at himself. I really enjoyed my time here until this Wednesday and obviously some bad days are expected. So I kind of expect that everything will be better next week (in case I make it). I also acknowledge that you have to deal with a very diverse bunch of students from different backgrounds, with different prior skill levels, different intelligence… so you can not make it work for all the people all the time. Pairing provides a ton of benefits, but the balance of pairing to solo time does not seem optimal to my learning.  I realize this may not be the case for everyone so I plan to address this with a few teachers to determine the best way to optimize my learning even if the balance doesn't change.

In complete sincerity, this continues to be the happiest I've been in years (even when I'm in the panic zone) so I just want to continue to say thanks for being here.

After lunch, there's another 1h -1.5hr lecture and then coding for 3-4 hours before most of the instructors leave. I feel a bit overwhelmed with all the challenges and projects I have, and not being able to dive and actually get stuff done. I think the lectures are helpful, but they need to be more focused and much shorter. Sometimes I think the lecture just drags on and it becomes an open forum for people to just talk about whatever for however long. 

I also feel a bit frustrated having to "do over" some activities such as Wednesday empathy and the check in intro with the banana slugs. With all the work we have, every hour counts and having to sit through an hour of something I've already done seems a bit wasteful.

I've been thinking a lot about my "optimal learning", and how I learn the most and the fastest. For me personally, I learn the most and fastest when I'm solo-ing. I look forward to every Thursday because I not only get the most amount of work done this day compared to any other day, but I also fully understand the material and learn the most. I would really like to be able to solo more often. I realize that being able to explain to someone how to do something truly validates understanding, however when I'm personally learning something completely foreign and brand new with someone else, it's difficult to move at the same pace. When I'm able to solo, learn something and get something working, I'm actually more motivated to get up and go help someone else with the newfound knowledge I've figured out. Going further with this concept, I feel like it's a bit unfair to be forced to help the other cohort for an hour out of my day when I only have 4-5 hours of coding time in the day, especially on the solo day when I'm learning the most. Again, once I got a lot of work done, I was more motivated to get up and go help someone else.

This week was challenging material and I feel like I learned SO MUCH even if it was 80% of what they'd like us to get. There's a certain switching cost to getting new teachers for only 3 week chunks; adapting to different people's approaches and just getting comfortable working with them definitely made last week less efficient than it could have been. I don't know if we're going to switch again for phase 3 but I would happily continue with them. 

I second maybe doing engineering empathy Fri night or perhaps Sat afternoon. Wednesday is hard because we're in the middle of the weekly grind so it IS time away from trying to master new material and it IS likely to be emotionally draining in one way or another. It's hard to do that when you're trying to finish stuff from the day and know you have to get up the next day and get thru a full day of challenges and new content. Going into the weekend it would be more manageable; gives a little more chance to process what comes up and decompress. 

Sherif (in addition to Shereef) totally called us out on not helping the slugs enough so I'm going to call him out on shaming us. Being super honest here, I want to help them. I want to get to know them as individuals, and I think we mostly all feel that way. The people aspect of this has been one of the more surprising and rewarding elements of this, in terms of what a collection of truly decent human beings are here and how much I've enjoyed working with them. But we're doing these big challenges that can easily be 6, 7 hour chunks to complete (it's like every day has turned into group project day) and when I'm barely keeping my head above water with what's going on with my app, it's such a huge switching cost. If I was more comfortable with what I was working on, which I essentially never am given how much more there is to master each day, the switch from one back to the other would be much easier. I don't know how to solve that for you guys. I think previous cohorts are the ideal people to have helping out, I've worked with a few of them and they've been incredibly helpful.

column17: The only thing I've found frustrating was the amount of pair coding we do.  I'm sure I'm not the first person to make the "too much pair coding" argument, but here goes- For me there seems to be two pieces to my process: working on the problem conceptually, and then working on implementing.  I have found, thus far, that I feel comfortable with the conceptual portion before some of my partners, and as a result, I'm ready to get going with implementation when they're still working on conceptualizing the problem.  It frustrates me, because the time consumed in this eats up time for things like stretch problems, where the conceptual element is very difficult, but that's the part I'm really interested in.  The most fun assignment was Quad, even though it was super late, and I was fried, because it requires a lot of time just staring at it.  I realize real world coding requires an ability to work with others and communicate your ideas with others in a meaningful way, but personally, I would prefer more of a balance between solo/pairs.

I think the pace is pretty good right now and I definitely feel challenged. The only thing I would like more of is ease of getting help. Also, it might be a good idea to get help other than calling somebody over since it's less efficient. Maybe instant messaging? Dont know what the answer is. I do agree that the more question we ask, the more we learn.

Also, we should start peer to peer teaching soon. This will be helpful especially for students feeling a little bit behind. Right now the p2p teaching only happens occasionally by chance. An allotted time where people feeling comfortable with one topic can teach others will be very helpful.

There are times when I would like to break away from pairing and just get personal time with a teacher. For example, once during a pairing session, I felt that my pair was resisting my urge to put the sticky note up and get clarification on certain things - and I wanted to ask a teacher, because my pair was not explaining the answer in a way that I could understand. In a way, I felt I was on a completely different thinking level than my pair and at times, I couldn't follow their logic even though it was correct. 

I think I would benefit from a smaller, one on one type of question and answer session when there is a problem, I don't understand. And for the most part, I have been able to create this one on one environment with a pair that I can easily understand and follow. But when I find my pair hard to understand, when and how, can I pull myself out of that situation and find someone who I can more fully understand  without offending my pair or deserting them for the help of another. 

I felt I was wasting time at certain points, when I felt I could be spending it learning the answer to a problem that in return I could then come back to my pair and be more of a help because I had now gained that clarification. (When the pair is unable to clarify.)

Things I love! ---
I really enjoyed the check-in exercise. I was reassuring to know that others are having the same feelings and that the anxiety/nervousness was shared across the board. It was also helpful to know that other, more advance, cohorts are still struggling with the drowning feeling and that it isn't an abnormal feeling. 

Things that could change---
While Zee is a great teacher and presenter, I feel that because he is so advanced in regard to keyboard shortcuts and maneuvers on the screen, that it can be difficult at times to follow what he is doing. For example, when he is testing and making very fast changes on the screen, I think it would be beneficial to some, if that process was slowed down a bit. I am glad to not see VIM used during presentations. 

That's all! 

Thanks for reading and allowing me to voice my opinions.

I had a super hard time on Monday. I felt unprepared and overwhelmed and out of place. Not in terms of Ruby or the challenges, but in terms of logistics and figuring boring housekeeping stuff out. I understand why we were told to ask the other cohorts stuff like where the bathroom is and how to get a locker, but the problem is we don't know what we don't know, if that makes sense. You don't know that there are 2 different codes to the doors until you get locked out. In defense of the other cohorts, Monday already feels like so long ago, for them it must feel like a million years. We're so focused on being here, existing here, it's easy to forget what life is like outside of this place, so it's easy to forget what people need to know when they're new. I finally found the student handbook, "Socrates/Labs" is the last place I looked for it. For me, that's not a very intuitive place to keep that. I would have really liked to have been able to read that before Monday. Monday was so overwhelming with the people and the challenges, that having to figure out the minutiae of whether there would be space in the fridge for my lunch just really stressed me out.
As terrible and dejected as I felt at the end of the day Monday, I woke up Tuesday morning feeling great. I realized that I feel pretty confident that I can work through any problem, eventually. Tuesday and Wednesday both were amazing. Particularly, on Wednesday, I had a super fun time pairing with Zee for part of a challenge. It would be really cool if everyone got to pair with a teacher for some small thing. It helped that I was pairing with Zee, since he's so much fun and nice. I find the Shereef&Sherif a little intimidating. Or at least, I still did on Wednesday. Which is silly because they are very nice. I'm working on it.
Thursday was tough. I felt like a failure for not being able to finish the core challenges. But at the same time I liked that I could not stop thinking about Boggle. Instead of feeling frustrated and defeated, I felt like I was really close and I just needed to step back and come back to the problem with a clear head. I think finding that sweet spot where I'm no longer producing anything useful and before I hit my breaking point is going to be hard for me.
I really like yoga. On Wednesday I was excited to go, because I felt good about the amount I had accomplished in the morning. On Friday I didn't want to go because I was worried about the Sudoku Solver. But once I got there on Friday I was glad to have gone and I felt much calmer when I came back.
The check-in was interesting. I think I liked it. I like having a place where I can just dump my feelings, since by the end of each day I'm so wound up. The part that made me uncomfortable was listening to other people's feelings. I don't know, I think I felt embarrassed to be listening? Like I was eavesdropping or like since these people would never tell me these things in person, that listening would be imposing. I'm not sure. I'm reserving judgement. 
I liked Jesse's talk on Thursday. It was super interesting and made me realize that I have a lot of my self worth wrapped up in my perception of my own intelligence as well. It really has a huge affect on my mood. So that's something I need to work on. 
I would love to see a weekly calendar with like check ins, yoga, speakers, just all the phase independent (or even some phase dependent stuff, like monday morning: phase 1 individual checkins with teachers). Just a loose outline. There's so much going on it's hard to remember what happens on what day.
Um okay this was mostly about me, but there is my feedback, for what it's worth.

In my opinion we have spent too much time doing Sinatra.
I would have introduced Rails in week 6.

Other than that, life is great.

I understand that we need to learn how to refactor code but wouldn't it be to your advantage to use non-refactored code when you're teaching in lecture so that those of us who are new can follow along more easily? Understanding is hard enough without that on top of it. I think refactoring can be learned closer to the end. Those people who already know how to do it can just do it but those of us who don't won't have to struggle with it right away.

I have feedback around the decision to ask people to leave and I prefer to discuss this with someone instead of writing my feedback here. I hope someone pulls me aside.

The last thing is I believe there should be some downtime for people to study. I want to succeed! And for me, especially as a newbie, means I need time to look over and study what I've done. 

I'll say again that I love the concept of Bootcamp style learning and I love writing code and the exercises you provide us. By the way the teachers are awesome. I love the silliness and play. That makes me happy. Slowing down and avoiding topics that are not so relevant to the intended lecture learning might be beneficial.
